articles.headline: McConnell Protégé Takes Center Stage in Fight to Remake Judiciary
articles.snippet: No stranger to partisan warfare at 37, Judge Justin Walker will go before the Senate Judiciary Committee, which is considering him for a seat on the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.
articles.abstract: No stranger to partisan warfare at 37, Judge Justin Walker will go before the Senate Judiciary Committee, which is considering him for a seat on the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In March, after Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh took time off from his Supreme Court duties to swear in Justin Walker to the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Kentucky in Louisville, the newly minted judge recognized how he had gotten there at the age of 37, with zero trial experience but a pedigree in conservatism.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Williamson and Rebecca R. Ruiz

articles.headline: A Wendy’s With No Burgers as Meat Production Is Hit
articles.snippet: Hundreds of the fast-food chain’s locations aren’t serving hamburgers and grocery stores are limiting meat purchases, as shoppers begin to feel the impact of meatpacking plant shutdowns.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of the fast-food chain’s locations aren’t serving hamburgers and grocery stores are limiting meat purchases, as shoppers begin to feel the impact of meatpacking plant shutdowns.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of Wendy’s restaurants have run out of hamburgers. Kroger, the largest supermarket chain in the United States, is limiting the amount of ground beef and pork that customers can buy at some stores. And Costco, where shoppers typically buy in bulk, has placed a three-product cap on purchases of fresh beef, poultry and pork.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: California Sues Uber and Lyft, Claiming Workers Are Misclassified
articles.snippet: The ride-hailing companies are accused of defying a new state law that says gig workers should be treated as employees.
articles.abstract: The ride-hailing companies are accused of defying a new state law that says gig workers should be treated as employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — California’s attorney general and a coalition of city attorneys in the state sued Uber and Lyft on Tuesday, claiming the companies wrongfully classified their drivers as independent contractors in violation of a state law that makes them employees.

articles.headline: Didn’t Get Your Stimulus Payment Yet? Here’s What to Do
articles.snippet: Tens of millions of people have already received their payments, but if you haven’t, these are the things you should check on.
articles.abstract: Tens of millions of people have already received their payments, but if you haven’t, these are the things you should check on.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s been weeks since people started getting coronavirus relief payments. You’ve checked and rechecked your eligibility, just to be sure.

articles.headline: Private Equity, Lobbying the U.S. for Help, Is Mostly Hearing ‘No’
articles.snippet: As the government rolls out trillions of dollars in emergency stimulus funds, a push by the industry has met with only modest success.
articles.abstract: As the government rolls out trillions of dollars in emergency stimulus funds, a push by the industry has met with only modest success.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since March, when the federal government began extending trillions of dollars in aid to companies and investors battered by the pandemic, some of the country’s biggest private equity firms have lobbied hard to shape the stimulus in their favor.
articles.byline: By Kate Kelly and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: This Working Man Was Ready to Retire. But the Virus Took Him.
articles.snippet: A journey down several blocks of one Pennsylvania city tells the story of the virus in America — of illness, financial strain and rising tension.
articles.abstract: A journey down several blocks of one Pennsylvania city tells the story of the virus in America — of illness, financial strain and rising tension.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAZLETON, Pa. — Just off Wyoming Street in Pennsylvania’s hilly, working-class city of Hazleton, Laury Sorensen and her husband, Emil, lugged groceries from a pickup truck upstairs to her parents’ wood-frame home.

articles.headline: How Kushner’s Volunteer Force Led a Fumbling Hunt for Medical Supplies
articles.snippet: Young, inexperienced workers scrambled to sort through tips on equipment desperately needed to fight the coronavirus while warehouses ran bare and doctors made their own gear.
articles.abstract: Young, inexperienced workers scrambled to sort through tips on equipment desperately needed to fight the coronavirus while warehouses ran bare and doctors made their own gear.
articles.lead_paragraph: This spring, as the United States faced a critical shortage of masks, gloves and other protective equipment to battle the coronavirus pandemic, a South Carolina physician reached out to the Federal Emergency Management Agency with an offer of help.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore, Andrew Jacobs, Jodi Kantor, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Luis Ferré-Sadurní

articles.headline: People Are Panic-Buying Meat, Toilet Paper … and Pelotons?
articles.snippet: With gyms closed and nowhere to go, more people are shelling out $2,245 for the workout bike.
articles.abstract: With gyms closed and nowhere to go, more people are shelling out $2,245 for the workout bike.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lauren Allbright, a teacher, children’s book author and triathlete, was antsy from weeks of sheltering in place. So last month, she “panic bought” a $2,245 Peloton bike.

articles.headline: How My Boss Monitors Me While I Work From Home
articles.snippet: As we shelter in place in the pandemic, more employers are using software to track our work — and us.
articles.abstract: As we shelter in place in the pandemic, more employers are using software to track our work — and us.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — On April 23, I started work at 8:49 a.m., reading and responding to emails, browsing the news and scrolling Twitter. At 9:14 a.m., I made changes to an upcoming story and read through interview notes. By 10:09 a.m., work momentum lost, I read about the Irish village where Matt Damon was living out the quarantine.

articles.headline: In a Town Split by a Border, Virus Rules Vary From Door to Door
articles.snippet: Life in one of the world’s most complex border towns was made even more puzzling when Dutch and Belgian officials took very different approaches to handling the coronavirus.
articles.abstract: Life in one of the world’s most complex border towns was made even more puzzling when Dutch and Belgian officials took very different approaches to handling the coronavirus.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAARLE-HERTOG-NASSAU — With the border dividing the Netherlands and Belgium cutting straight through the entrance of her studio and art gallery, Sylvia Reijbroek was confused over which country’s rules to follow when the coronavirus upended Europe.
